title: I have a question about a debt collection law suit placed against me
question: I recently noticed a charge and closed debt owed from a company called Persolve LLC, on my credit report. I called the number to inquire about it, and they told me that I was being sued for an amount owed from 2007, which I remember closing. They insisted that they filed a law suit, by sending a process server to my home, who then served the papers to an unknown person to me. I doubt they even visited my home, and then they proceeded to take the suit to court. Which they claim is now as a charge against me that will stay on my credit report for the next ten years, or until I pay the amount owed; which they were trying to get me to do in order for me to get that taken off my account.
question_tags: LLC (limited liability company),Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Discovery,Sued for debt,Default judgment
answers:
Persolve is a debt purchase company.
If you were not properly served, you may reopen case and set judgment aside. Check the court file.
Facts indicate you may be entitled to damages under various federal and state laws. Reference: FDCPA/RFDCPA and FCRA.
Review all facts with BK counsel.
I would highly recommend contacting my receptionist, I would love to help you in any way I can.

Persolve is a debt buyer. It buys portfolios of delinquent account from creditors, including credit card companies. It appears that they obtained a default judgment against you. The judgment is a public record and may be reported on your credit report. I doubt that you will be able to get Persolve to drop the matter. And, even if you pay them the full amount (including interest), they cannot change a public record. What you need to do is to review the court file at the courthouse and get copies of the relevant documents, including the Proof of Service form, which states the date, time and place of the purported service of process. If the proof of service is not correct, you need to retain an attorney and have the attorney file a motion to vacate the default judgment and allow you to defend the lawsuit in court. You may also have a basis for suing the creditor and/or the collector for violations of the federal and California Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In many cases, if you win, you can collect attorney's fees from the other side.

You should contact an attorney near you experienced in unfair debt collection and debt defense. They can assist you with a set aside and defending this matter as well as your potential FDCPA/RFDCPA and FCRA claims/counterclaims against the debt collector.

There are many excellent attorneys who focus on this area of law with an office near you and provide free consultation. Also, try using NACA's Find an Attorney page: http://www.consumeradvocates.org/find-attorney.

I am not entirely sure what your question is, but if you truly never got notice of the lawsuit being filed, that should be sufficient grounds to have the judgment vacated (removed). This does not end the matter, however, it just means that at that time, you would be able to file an answer, conduct discovery and argue your position. Consult with a consumer attorney in your area for details.
